section.title: Reading Assignment
section.p: Read Section 11.1 of Applied Discrete Structures. This is the beginning of a new topic, but you'll find that there are connections between algebra and graph theory. In this first section we review properties of binary operations.

statement.p: True or False? Multiplication is an associative operation on the set \{-1,1\}. Justify your answer.

section.p: Also, turn in solutions to these exercises:

statement.p: Explain why subtraction is not an associative operation on the integers.

solution.p: A counterexample to the associative property is all that is needed here, of which there are an infinite number of examples. One such is 1-(2-3)\neq (1-2)-3.

statement.p: Write out the operation table for intersection on the \mathcal{P}(\{0,1\}), the power set of \{0,1\}.
What properties that are introduced in Secton 11.1 are true of intersection on the power set of \{0,1\}?.

Consider the operation \square on the integers defined by a \square b = a+b-1.
Is \square associative?
Does \square have an identity in the positive integers?
Does \square have the inverse property?

li.p:
Yes, it is associative:
(a \square b)\square c= (a+b-1)\square c = a+b-1+c-1 = a+b+c-2 a \square(b \square c)= a \square(b+c-1) = a+(b+c-1)-1 = a+b+c-2
If e is an identity, we would need a \square e=a+e-1 = a. Solving a+e-1 = a for e, we see that 1 is an identity.

No, the inverse of a postitive integer a would be b such that a \square b=1. Therefore a+b-1=1, or b=-a+2. But since we assume a is a positive integer b is not positive unless a = 1, and so only 1 have an inverse.

statement.p: This question is open-ended, with no specific right answer. Suppose that V is some finite nonempty set. What would be an example of a binary operation on the set of all undirected graphs with vertex setV?
